For that, the Liberal Party is proposing to give the Government a period of stability. Therefore, we find the Liberal Party, like Harcourt, saying "We are all Socialists now" and the Prime Minister saying "We are all Liberals now".
I suggest that it will be a very interesting joint committee that will be chaired by the Leader of the House. My memory goes back to the days when we were at Oxford together. The right hon. Gentleman was chairman of the Liberal Club. What he used to say about Socialism was really quite remarkable. The right hon. Gentleman would quote Lloyd George about sand in the wheels and all the rest of it. Socialism was a terrible thing. But the right hon. Member for Ebbw Vale (Mr. Foot) is now a Socialist. Indeed, he is not just a Member of the Labour Party. At one time he was the shining light of the Left wing of the Labour Party—the Tribune Group. I warn Liberal Members that they are treading on a dangerous slope when they go in company with the right hon. Member for Ebbw Vale.
I must be short, Mr. Deputy Speaker, in the interests of other Members who wish to address the House. I wonder whether Liberal Members will give the stability that they think they are going to give to the Government. I suggest that the Government that they are proposing to support at 10 o'clock tonight are a very strange Government. They are a ruinous Government, dilapidated beyond repair. They remind me of the hut in Grimm's Fairy Tales which
remained standing because it was so ruinous that it could not decide which way to fall. The Liberal Party is telling the hut which way to fall—and doing it with a fine irony in the name of accommodation.
My closing words of warning to Liberal Members must be that at the end of the day, which is not many months distant, they will find themselves without accommodation, without friends, without reputation, and without a future.

I assure the hon. and learned Member for Beaconsfield (Mr. Bell) that the House enjoyed his performance almost as much as he enjoyed himself. The hon. and learned Gentleman took us along many byways. I know that he will forgive me if I do not follow him too seriously on his recent and Biblical analogies.
This confidence debate concentrates our minds, in the same way as they were concentrated last Thursday, on one of the most repugnant and obscene affairs of our Parliamentary deliberations. As my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister said, we have a minority Government. The result of a vote of confidence in such circumstances can rest entirely upon which side has the most Members sick at one moment and how many are in hospital beds rather than on the Floor of the Chamber.
My hon. Friend the Member for East Kilbride (Dr. Miller), who is the doctor in the House, has spent his time during the course of the debate looking at the sick downstairs. It must be incomprehensible to the public outside that the Mother of Parliaments, on a matter of supreme importance—a vote of confidence in the Government and whether to have a General Election—should have ambulances coming into New Palace Yard bringing in among others, a Member with a coronary thrombosis, and that decision has to be made in order to ascertain whether he can be brought in to vote. I hope that, having reached that situation, yet again the usual channels will now consider it for future occasions, because inevitably with a minority Government there will be a repetition.
The statement at the weekend by a Conservative Whip urging his colleagues
not to go hunting in case they broke their necks, because he could not afford to lose their votes, bordered on the ludicrous. I do not know whether he felt that they should not go shooting or fishing in case they fell in the water and caught colds.
Much of the debate has hinged on the arrangements made and being made between my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister and the right hon. Member for Roxburgh, Selkirk and Peebles (Mr. Steel). I think that most people in politics would like to be pure white and not have to enter into compromises about anything, but rarely do we get 100 per cent. of what we want.
There were obvious political motivations at work for my right hon. Friends in the Cabinet and the Liberal Party. I congratulate the Leader of the Liberal Party on his political considerations. I believe that he made the arrangement in the interests not only of his party but of the country. I hope that he will not consider me patronising when I say that in my experience in this House over many years colleagues who reach the leadership of the party or become Ministers have two options. Some grow and some swell. The Leader of the Liberal Party has grown considerably since he has held that office in his party. Of course, we shall argue and fight with him when our politics diverge and there will be differences of opinion. Nevertheless, as a result of his taking a commonsense approach, what has happened in the House today and what will happen in the Division tonight will mean that for a few months arrangements will be discussed with which he will be able to agree or disagree.
Most of the argument in today's debate has concentrated on the Government's problems, its economic and industrial strategy, its social strategy and the handling of public expenditure. Together with many of my hon. Friends, I have had differences with the Government over some aspects of the public expenditure cuts, but I hope to put this into perspective.
Let us look at the balance between the nation's spending in the public and private sectors. I often recall walking down Oxford Street at Christmas and looking for the poverty of the workers as they went in and out of the shops on
a huge spending spree. We have just received figures which show that—and I make no complaint about this because workers are entitled to spend their money as they choose—we spent £2,237 million on cigarettes and tobacco, £3,927 million on alcoholic drink and £2,600 million on bingo and gambling in 1974. That is twice as much as we spend on the whole of the hospital service. There is no reason why we should not choose to spend our money in that way, but I cannot believe that my Government are causing intense poverty to ordinary people when so much money can be spent in the private sector.
The Opposition speak—as they used to say in the boys' comics of years ago—with forked tongues. In every area of need, they are prepared to attack the Government and to call on them to give or do more. This applies to spending on the elderly, the sick, the disabled and cars instead of tricycles. Yet the Opposition also call at the same time for cuts in public expenditure. I must defend the Government's record since we came into office in 1974.
I support my Government for the way in which, when the going has been tough, the financial climate has been difficult and there has been no easy option, they have invariably chosen to give the best possible deal to the poor, the sick and the disabled. That is the basis of my support for the Government and my condemnation of the Opposition motion.
In the few minutes that are left to me, I wish to speak about my confidence in the Government and lack of confidence in the Opposition. The area of public concern with which I have most contact is that of the National Health Service. The House will not be surprised that I look to that Department in seeking an example of my Government's record.
Following customary practice, I dropped a line to the right hon. Member for Leeds, North-East (Sir K. Joseph) to inform him that I intended to talk tonight about his track record on National Health Service expenditure. The right hon. Gentleman, who has considerable influence on Opposition benches on economic policy, recommended that an American consultant company, McKinsey, should compile a report to restructure
the administration of the National Health Service. That report cost the taxpayers £22,000. It was intended to reorganise the National Health Service on more efficient lines, but it led to one of the greatest bureaucratic administrative monstrosities of all time. Having delivered the report and received the money, that same company said only a few weeks ago that it was sorry but it had got things wrong. But it was up to the Conservative Government to reject the advice—the decision was theirs—but they did not do so.
Every hon. Member will be able to recognise the example that I shall give relating to my own constituency, and no doubt every hon. Member has similar figures. My local area health authority employs 196 administrators at a total cost of £829,443 a year. The Royal College of Nursing made the point admirably today when it said that it was time that we took a scalpel to the administration and put more effort into the treatment, care and prevention of disease instead of building up larger amounts of paper, committees, consultations and the liaisons that go on as a result of the way in which the reorganisation Act of 1973 has decided to run the Health Service.
Since my Government took office, the amount spent on hospital administration has risen from £51 million in 1973 –74 to £121 million in 1974 –75. This is the direct result of the 1973 Act. If the Opposition win the vote tonight, there could be an election and, Lord forbid, there could be a Conservative Government, so I intend to compare Opposition policies with what my Government have been able to do in difficult circumstances.
When this Government came into office, the amount that was being spent on the National Health Service was about 4·9 per cent. of the gross national product. As a result of the Labour Government's administration, in which I have the greatest confidence, we are now spending 6·7 per cent. of our gross national product on the National Health Service for the first time. We are spending £6,800 million every year on looking after the sick.
Nurses who for generations have been underpaid and overworked, for the first time, received a fair deal in April 1974. The Government have also given a fair deal to junior doctors that they were not getting before.
When I hear the way in which my Scottish colleagues argue about devolution, I feel that I must remind them that although we spend £4 per head of population on health in England, we spend £5 per head in Scotland. The Scots should appreciate this benefit of the United Kingdom when they go into the devolution talks. I could give the House details of the situation in the United States where £12 is spent per head of population on health services compared with £4 per head in this country. I could go on, but I shall not do so.
The Government have done a good job of work here—even though they are not perfect. When you, Mr. Deputy Speaker, and I are perfect, I shall expect my Government to be perfect. Perfection cannot exist this side of paradise. My Government do and will make mistakes, but they have achieved an enormous amount in spite of the difficulties.
The Opposition should remember that when there are quarrels inside a family—and every family has quarrels—if the neighbours try to interfere the family will immediately unite. The Treasury Bench need have no fear. If we are attacked by the Opposition, our family will stand together, will have every confidence in the Government, and support them, especially when under attack from their opponents.

The hon. Member for Hammersmith, North (Mr. Tomney) said that in putting down this motion the Tory Party was out of touch with the electorate. Since I and two or three of my hon. Friends have recently been in the closest possible touch with the electorate in the way that counts—by looking for their support—I am particularly pleased to be able to say a few things in this debate.
Any Government obtains their authority from three separate but overlapping sources. They receive authority from the constituency—the people and the popularity of their policies—from parliamentary solidarity and strength, and from a moral sense, which is a feeling that the country at large—not necessarily just politicians—believes that the Government are not abusing their supreme authority, but are using it in the long-term best interests
of the nation, that they are not putting it at the disposal of some special specific faction. I shall look briefly at each of these three.
First, at constituency level: there are 72,000 electors in Walsall, North. Prior to the by-election in November, the Labour Party held the seat with a majority of almost 16,000. It is now a Conservative seat with a majority of more than 4,000—there has been a swing of about 20,000. The hon. Member for Liverpool, Walton (Mr. Heffer) may claim that this massive turn-round was caused by the effects of the incomes policy. That policy was an important factor, but the hon. Gentleman is mistaken if he thinks that it was the only one. There were other equally important factors at play in the campaign and in the country.
These factors included the importance to the average working man of seeing his hard-earned money being taken away in taxes and wasted by the Government in poor administration and in schemes, such as nationalisation, that are irrelevant to the nation's needs. The people of Walsall, North also changed their voting habits because they were frightened by increases in crime and by the actions of a Government who condoned law-breaking and thereby undermined respect for authority.
Voting habits were changed because of restrictions on the freedom of choice. If there is one thing that the English people dislike above all others it is a busybody. Interfering petty officials have had a field day under this Government.
Those were the reasons for the choice made by the people of Walsall, and a similar choice was being made at the same time in other parts of the country, including Workington. It is clear, therefore, that the part of the Government's authority that comes from the electoral popularity of its policies has withered away.
The Government's parliamentary authority is no more satisfactory, and not just in the immediate issue that we are facing, although spending is at least as important as revenue raising and if there is a similar result following the Budget proposals, there will be even more of a storm than we have witnessed in the past few days.
It is not just a question of the approval of specific policies. There is also the Government's failure to carry crucial and important legislation—the devolution Bill is the centrepiece of their legislative programme for this Session. In fact, it is not even only their failure to carry that legislation. They have failed to bring forward legislation because they know that it will be lost. They have not brought in the Bill to provide for direct elections to the European Parliament, and that takes us into an even more serious default.
Direct elections to the European Parliament concern not only this country but our allies and friends abroad. The Government have jeopardised not only the position of this country, but our prestige and reputation around the world. For these reasons it can be said that the Government's parliamentary authority has been chipped away.
Finally, I turn to moral authority, which is possibly the most important, if least tangible, source of the Government's strength. The Government must face the fact that it is widely considered that they have given sectional claims priority over the needs of the nation as a whole. As a result, many policies have been adopted that are, at best, irrelevant to the nation's needs, and, at worst, downright harmful to our long-term prospects.
Hon. Members opposite will claim that nothing has been done that was not in the Labour Party's manifesto at the last General Election, but, as was pointed out earlier, there was no mention in that manifesto of deals with the Liberal Party.
The Government have lost and forfeited their authority and right to govern. No doubt hon. Members opposite will disagree. They may be right; they certainly have more parliamentary experience than I, but they must admit that there is at least a possibility that they are wrong. The one thing on which we can all agree is the value of the democratic franchise. If hon. Members opposite are right, why should they be frightened to put it to the test? Let us put it to the test by putting it to the people. Anyone who is a democrat will be supporting the motion in the Division.

In reply to the hon. Member for Walsall,
North (Mr. Hodgson), the plain unvarnished truth is that we believe that if we put it to the people now, we would lose. It is also the plain unvarnished truth that the Leader of the Opposition wants to put it to the electorate because she thinks that she will win. However, it is interesting to note that in the past week, the Press, which is not altogether friendly to my party, has been almost unanimous in agreeing that this is not the time, in the national interest, to have a General Election. Apart from the Tory hack papers such as the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph, most of the papers have resisted the claim of the Leader of the Opposition that the country and the Tory Party are thirsting for a General Election.
One of my hon. Friends mentioned earlier the surprising difference between the statements made by Conservative Members in the House, when they know they will be widely reported, and what they say privately. There are 600 vested interests in this House who do not want a General Election. The Observer summed it up well on Sunday when it said: The case against a Thatcher Government coming to power … is that too little is known of Conservative anti-inflation policies. We have heard some witty speeches from hon. Members opposite, but they have been entirely barren of the policies that the public have a right to know about before putting their crosses on the ballot paper. The Leader of the Opposition spent a good deal of time saying precisely nothing about these policies.
Will the hon. Gentleman give way?

I have whacked the hon. Gentleman so many times that it would be a waste of time for me to give way to him again.
I apologise for taking up the time of the House by quoting from respectable newspapers. I would not do so but for the fact that they support my case. The Times said last week about the Government: for the moment it does not appear to be prevented by the weakness of its parliamentary position from doing anything that is essential in the national interest. The same editorial said that there was not sufficient cause to precipitate an election next week
One may therefore ask who honestly and passionately wants an election before another glorious summer is upon us. Whatever hon. Members opposite may say publicly, the vast majority admit in private that they do not want an election. No more and no less than my party, the Conservatives are a series of minority parties. We have seen the petty type of tactic being operated this evening with Conservative hon. Members occupying the Liberal Benches. When I look at the Liberal Bench I do not suppose that that bunch of Tories could muster an 1Q of 103 between them.
The person who passionately wants to take the plunge in a General Election is the Leader of the Opposition.
So do we.

I shall examine the right hon. Lady's motivation. It is completely honourable. With the demise of one lady Prime Minister in the world she desperately wants to go down in history as the first female Prime Minister in the British calendar. That all-consuming passion has warped her judgment and whetted her fancy as surely as if she had become a drug addict. She may have no policies

On a point of order, Mr. Deputy Speaker. Is it in order for an hon. Member to suggest that my right hon. Friend the Leader of the Opposition is comparable with a drug addict? I suspect that you would not agree to that.
I do not understand what the hon. Member's point of order is. What is it?
It is disgraceful expression.
It is not in order and it is uparliamentary for the hon. Member to suggest that the Leader of the Opposition is comparable with a drug addict.
Disgraceful Withdraw.

I do not know whether the hon. Member For Fife, Central (Mr. Hamilton) will save me the
trouble of ruling by withdrawing the words. As I understand it, he is only making a comparison. He is not suggesting that the right hon. Lady is a drug addict.

Hon. Members misheard what I said. I shall repeat my words and then you, Mr. Deputy Speaker, can rule upon them. I said that the all-consuming passion that the right hon. Lady has—I wanted to be in order because I am very much a parliamentarian—

On a point of order, Mr. Deputy Speaker. The hon. Member for Fife, Central (Mr. Hamilton) is clearly reading his speech. He has said that he is. Can you stop that nonsense? It is not in order to read a speech.

I did not expect that we should get into this mood this evening on such serious business. The debate has been well conducted so far. I suggest that we get on with it so that we can hear the final speeches from the Front Benches and reach the all-important vote.
Hon. Members have been labouring under a misunderstanding. I was saying—
Withdraw.
Order. It would help the hon. Member if he addressed himself to the Chair. He would then get a smoother ride.

I was making a comparison. The warping of the right hon. Lady's judgment, in her anxiety to become the first female Prime Minister, makes her like a drug addict. That is a perfectly proper comparison to make.

On a point of order, Mr. Deputy Speaker. Is it parliamentary language and is it in order for the hon. Member to say that my right hon. Friend the Leader of the Opposition is behaving like a drug addict? I do not think that it is.

So far as I can judge, the hon. Member for Fife, Central is trying to compare the right hon. Lady's actions with those of a drug addict. He is not suggesting that the Leader of the Opposition is a drug addict.

Hon. Members are consuming the time of the House. The next speaker is a Tory hon. Member and I do not wish to prevent any hon. Member from speaking. However, as a result of these interventions my speech will be that much longer.
I was remarking that the right hon. Lady and all those who purport to support her in the debate may have no policies. Her team on the Front Bench makes Dad's Army look like a crack regiment. That which is lacking in policies and personalities the right hon. Lady seeks to make up by using her polished phrases and her blue rinsed coiffure.
The right hon. Lady knows that the time factor is now not on her side. The trends in the economy, which were spelt out by the Prime Minister this afternoon, are all in the right direction. The pound is stable, the rate of increase in inflation has been slowed down and unemployment may have passed its highest peak. Next week we shall get a very favourable Budget, and next year will see North Sea oil getting rid of our overseas borrowings and we shall see a healthy balance of payments surplus within a period of 12 to 18 months.
What the national interest requires now, it seems to me—and, apparently, to most of the newspapers—is a period of steady, unspectacular government, working in co-operation with organised labour in the form of the TUC and with capital in the form of the CBI—
With the Liberals.

—and with our people as a whole, in terms of the social contract, towards the goals of prosperity and peace both at home and abroad. That seems to be the broad policy at which we must aim.
I come now to the deal, the agreement or the understanding—call it what one will—that has been arrived at by the Government and the Liberal Party. I believe that at present the country prefers government by affable Uncle Jim to government by the excitable, unpredictable, aggressive Iron Lady.
Put it to the test.

We shall put it to the test, but not at a time of the Conservative Party's choosing.
The realities of the present Parliament demand accommodations
The Labour Party will be out lock, stock and barrel.

—with such minority interests as are reasonable in their demands. The Liberals in this House are a nice bunch of lads requiring special treatment, and we shall give it to them. Their demands were not unreasonable. I can happily go along with most of them. My colleagues in the Tribune Group may be nice as well—though not quite as nice, perhaps. They are more numerous, for sure, and a large number of them represent marginal seats, so they need just that little bit of coaxing to vote for the continued survival of old uncle at No. 10. The more troublesome of them can always be accommodated within the Government.
Scottish National Party Members can be written off as Tories, anyway. They will be going into the Lobby with the Opposition tonight. Many of them would bridle at any concessions made to them. I have often talked about the Scottish economy. In the context of this debate and in this connection, my hon. Friends should know that there is now a project in hand worth £200 million in oil investment by Shell-Esso in Fife. My SNP opponent condemned that outright as soon as it was announced. That was a £200 million investment in the county of Fife. We can write off the SNP in that context.
I say to my right hon. Friends, however, that there are other minority groups in the Labour Party who need to be considered. I was a bit concerned when my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister referred this afternoon to a document that none of us has yet seen. That is the long document presented by the Liberal Party on the devolution Bill. Some of us would like to see that document. I hope that we shall see it in full in good time, and before my right hon. Friends take action on it I hope that they will consider the views of minorities such as myself in these matters. We are just as important as the Liberal Party. We shall have something to say about the
Bill and about its process through the House. I do not believe that the proposition presented by the hon. Member for South Ayrshire (Mr. Sillars) is practical because the Government cannot link a motion on the guillotine to a motion of confidence. The two are completely unrelated.

On a point of order, Mr. Deputy Speaker. The recent Conservative converts to the Liberal Party, who are sitting on the opposite side of the House in the Liberal seats are making an awful racket. Could you do somethting to keep the children quiet?

I think that the hon. Members who have moved into the second row below the Gangway have not yet become acclimatised to their new surroundings. I think that some allowance needs to be made for that. I call Mr. Maurice Macmillan.

No, Mr. Deputy Speaker, I was asking a question of the Front Bench and I think my right hon. Friend the Leader of the House is about to reply to it.

I would say to my hon. Friend that we have already initiated discussions with regard to consultation among different sections of the Labour Party and, of course, there will be consultation with all sections of the Labour Party about the devolution Bill and the method on which we should proceed. This was already initiated even before we had discussions with the hon. Member for South Ayrshire (Mr. Sillars).

I would immediately accept that. The point I wanted to get clear was that the proposition put forward by the hon. Member for South Ayrshire is not a practical proposition. I do not think the Government should regard a motion on a guillotine as a
motion of confidence in themselves. I might have one view about the guillotine but quite another view about a motion of confidence. It would be grossly unfair and improper if the two were linked together.
The House will behave very sensibly tonight by voting for the continuation of an unabrasive and cool-headed Government. If it does so it will behave in the national interest. I am glad to see those capable Liberal faces newly on the Opposition Front Bench.

I want to refer briefly to one major reason why neither the House nor the country can or should have any confidence in the Government. It is the total failure to make any real effort to secure the proper defence of this country and to protect its essential trading and sea routes. Indeed, the Government have allowed our defences to run down to a level which even Labour Members on the Select Committee have declared to be already dangerously low.
Defence is the first duty of any Government of any kind, but it is in this, the first ad most important duty, that the Government have failed worst. It is particularly important to our survival as a trading nation since we are wholly dependent for our economy and our very existence on our capacity freely to import essential goods and raw materials.
We have heard from the Prime Minister a little bit about foreign affairs, detente, disarmament, and human rights throughout the world. Of course these are important matters, but they are not matters which by themselves constitute a positive foreign policy that can be of any help in protecting the weaker countries and in helping emergent territories to reach safe and secure government.
It is all very well to talk rather glibly about human rights and to ignore the effect of Communist-inspired dictatorships imposed by Cuban-led guerrillas in Africa. We have seen the extinguishing of human rights in Angola. There is the invasion of Zaire, which can only be a threat to all the people of that country.
In Africa it is not a question of black against white: it is a question of black dictatorship inspired from outside as opposed to internal rule by the Africans
independently and democratically. Even in Rhodesia Her Majesty's Government's policies have turned away from the whole concept of majority rule in favour of encouraging rule imposed by a minority in guerrilla dictatorship.
Apart from the protection of emergent countries from this sort of tyranny there is one other aspect of this pattern in which the Government have failed. I refer to its consequences for the West. Soviet domination of Africa, however achieved—Soviet control, however achieved, of the sea routes round the Cape—can lead only to a threat to the essential raw materials and the oil on which we all depend. It is Japan as well as Western Europe as a whole that is likely to be affected unless something is done.
The United Kingdom, however, is the most dependent of all, for we rely not only on the Cape route and the Southern Atlantic route but on the North Atlantic route, too. Here, again, the Government have failed to secure a naval building programme, an aircraft building programme, and a defence programme, which, incidentally, could bring a great deal of work to areas of high unemployment and in industries requiring a high degree of skill and technology.
I know that we are not a great Power, but Europe could be. Only yesterday I tabled a Question for Written Answer to the Prime Minister. In reply the right hon. Gentleman told me, in effect, that he had no intention of raising the whole subject of the defence of Western Europe and the securing of supplies to Western Europe in his discussions in the Council of Ministers and in Europe generally. He said, in effect, that defence had no part in the framing of a European foreign policy.
Perhaps it has no part officially, but no move towards a European foreign policy can be practical or sensible unless it considers the defence implications. It is surely up to the United Kingdom to take a lead in this. It is for their failure to take this lead, and for their failure in foreign policy and defence policy, that the Government should stand condemned. That alone is enough to justify the motion—that the House and the country have no confidence in the present Government.

There has been great anticipation of this debate—it is supposed to be a great parliamentary occasion. It was all to be a big drama, but I am afraid that the Conservatives are reducing it to a farce. It is a pity that the House of Commons proceedings are not televised, because then the public would be able to see the antics of Conservative old Etonians and Harrovians occupying the Liberal Benches like a bunch of members of St. Trinians. This sort of behaviour brings the Conservatives into disrepute. [Interruption.]
Order. I appeal to hon. Members to finish this debate peacefully.

When I heard the Leader of the Opposition moving the motion this afternoon I wondered whether the Tory Party really deserved her. But looking at Conservatives tonight, I have come to the conclusion that they do. We understood that she was going to visit China soon. After tonight members of her party probably will suggest that she goes on a slow boat. Her contribution today did not live up to the occasion.
Events have proved that there has been a massive political miscalculation by the Leader of the Opposition. Let us look at her timing. We all know that there will be a Budget within the next few days. One would have thought that before putting down a motion such as this the Tories would have heard the contents of that Budget and the deliberations on the Finance Bill. Then, if they were not satisfied, they could have decided to try to create a situation that would have forced this Government out of office. The timing was bad.
Again, there are the discussions with the trade union movement about phase 3. Whatever we may think about the Government—and some of us have quarrels with some aspects of Government policy—there is no doubt that they have been really successful in negotiating with the trade union movement over the past two years. It is sad that now that we are entering the third phase the Opposition should try to provoke a political crisis.
The Prime Minister has been successful in bringing a summit conference to
Downing Street of some of the leading industrial nations of the world. The problems confronting us as a country are faced by the whole of the Western world at the moment. When we look back at the last two and a half to three years, we see that the Government, who inherited a hopeless economic situation from the Conservatives, have brought about a quiet transformation. All the economic indicators point to the fact that our economic recovery is under way.
Why are the Tories so desperate? They realise that if they do not seize the initiative now all will be lost for them. That is why we are getting the political high jinks tonight and the nonsensical performance of Tories and the Liberal Member for Cornwall, North (Mr. Pardoe) over the seating arrangements.
I believe that nobody wants a General Election now. Reference has been made to the Stock Exchange. When the news reached the Stock Exchange about the confidence vote and there was a whisper that there might be a Tory Government, the stocks dropped by more than £1,000 million in a day. Of course they recovered when the news spread that we would hold on to power.
I must admit that that causes me some anxiety as there is little in common between the Stock Exchange and the Labour Party. However, it is an indication that industrialists and investors realise that the return of the Tory Government would mean going back to where we were three years ago—back to chaos. Those were the days when we had Ministers on the Tory Front Bench telling the country to shave in the dark. I give way to the hon. Member, who is sitting on the Opposition Front Bench.
rose—
What is going on?

Order. I have only just come back to the debate and I find this very interesting. Hon. Members normally address the House from the seat they are occupying and that is what the hon. Member for Cornwall, North (Mr. Pardoe) is doing. However, I hope that hon. Members will realise that the windup speeches begin at 9 p.m.

Will the hon. Gentleman accept that it was not only that matter
that indicated the lack of confidence of business in the last Tory Government, but that it was the failure of the City and industry to invest that indicated the lack of confidence of the business community in the—
Order. That is more than an intervention.

I agree with my hon. Friend. [HON. MEMBERS:" Oh."] I think that the hon. Gentleman is quite right in saying that the Tory Party has lost the confidence of business. What we should be discussing today is the direction that the Government should take. They have been confronted by a world recession, the quadrupling of oil prices, and many other difficulties. My right hon. Friend the Prime Minister has told us, and my right hon. Friend the Leader of the House will no doubt tell us more, of how much has been achieved already. The Tory Opposition are dismayed. They want to sit back and let the Labour Government do all the difficult tasks, including persuading the working people to make the sacrifices that they have made, and then they thought they would come along and do again what they did between 1970 and 1974—transform a surplus into a deficit once more.
The Government can put forward a good record. The Leader of the Opposition has failed to spell out what the Tory Party would do in office. It is reported that in the last few days the Tory Central Office has hurriedly prepared a manifesto on which the Tory Party intends to fight the next General Election. I hope that that manifesto will be published. I hope that at long last we shall find out where the Tory Party stands on the many issues with which the Government have had to deal.
I believe that we all know the results of the drama to be enacted tonight. I believe that the Tory Party has made a serious miscalculation. I believe that what will be decided in the next year or so is whether there is to be a change not of Government but in the leadership of the Tory Party.

I am certain that the House in no way underestimates the importance of the decision that it is to make at 10 o'clock.
It will make it in rather bizarre circumstances in which the Prime Minister has announced some kind of political shot-gun wedding. In the first few hours he has cause for some anxiety. There are some signs of physical desertion—certainly a reluctance to join him. He may find that the partnership will turn out to be of a rather curious nature.
But there is more at stake today than just any ordinary clash between Government and Opposition. We have a minority Government whose record and whose intentions are on trial. We have had minority Governments before in this country, and it is central to our case that this minority Government have not conducted themselves either in the manner or in the spirit of such a Government.
The Government have had ample time and ample incentive to do so, but they have refused. As their original overall majority has been reduced, then erased and then turned into a minority, they have given the impression of becoming more and more intransigent—until the reality of an actual defeat had some effect.
In moving this motion we are not simply expressing our opposition to Socialism, which is a mutual difference between the two sides of the House which, I am sure, will outlast the whole lot of us. We are saying that the results of the last three years' stewardship of the Government's responsibilities are so unsatisfactory that the prospect of the Government's continuance in office is unacceptable.
We are saying that the useful life of this Parliament is ended and that it must be renewed in the only proper way that it can be renewed—by the people who sent us here. The Government have only themselves to blame for the fact that they are facing this censure motion tonight. They have been behaving like a suicide squad. If by contortions they escape a defeat tonight, that will be a verdict that the country does not deserve, and I predict that the Liberals will live to regret it, because they have paid a price that they cannot afford for the life of this Government. That price is that the Liberals will keep the Socialists in power.
Both the Government and the Liberals have come to a political bargain the terms of which I believe must contravene the
Trade Descriptions Act. We have there a party still dedicated to State monopolisation of all means of production, distribution and exchange. There is not much room for the Liberals there, or for the mixed economy either. That party is trying desperately to prolong its own life by trying to arrange a marriage of temporary convenience with partners of a very different political philosophy—a one-night stand if ever there was one.
I should like to remind the Prime Minister of what he had to say about the possibility of forming a coalition three years ago. He said: It has no pride of ancestry and no hope of posterity. On what policies would this unfortunate hybrid animal be expected to graze? Of course this is not a coalition that the Prime Minister announced today. No one knows what it is, but it is not a coalition. We have yet to hear what he thinks of the arrangement.
At any rate, the Prime Minister had no difficulty in burying those words and those anxieties about making arrangements with another party. I think that he has infinitely the best of the bargain. I have to tell him—although he is not back in his place yet—that what he announced this afternoon has not exactly been received as a triumph among Labour Members, although, as far as we can tell, no criticism went as far as saying that support for the Government would be withheld.
I believe that my right hon. Friend the Member for Stafford and Stone (Mr. Fraser) was correct in saying that the Prime Minister undoubtedly got the better of the bargain. He is the tiger who has temporarily swallowed the lady of Riga. When the time comes, we all look forward to the animal being violently sick. We do not mind too much about the animal, but we mind a bit more about the lady.
Most of the manifesto on which the Labour Party was elected and its most Socialist proposals have now gone through the House, despite the opposition that we have put up against them. What the Prime Minister wants is a deal to see him through to the next manifesto of red-blooded Socialist proposals.
This arrangement has been designed to provide a breathing space between the last dose of Socialism and the next that
they hope to be able to introduce. It is a device for the survival of Socialism. Let me remind the House of what Lloyd George said after the first occasion on which the Liberal Party joined the Labour Party in forming a coalition over 50 years ago. He said that if the Liberals dared to criticise the Labour Government, they were visited with "peevish resentment". The Liberals, he said, were expected to be the oxen to drag Labour over the rough roads of Parliament for two or three years, and at the end of the journey, when there is no further use for them, they are to be slaughtered. That is the deal that has been done in the course of the last three days.
The Labour leopard does not change its spots just because it temporarily covers them up. The Parliamentary Liberal Party has neither responsibility nor power. How bankable does anybody in this House think is the undertaking by the Government to bring forward proportional representation for direct elections to Europe on a free vote? I do not think that the words of the Prime Minister or the right hon. Member for Roxburgh, Selkirk and Peebles (Mr. Steel) on this subject were in any way significant. I saw nothing significant in what they said about devolution, because, as we know, the Government have gone ahead with the talks on an inter-party basis anyway. The two sides have therefore got themselves into an extraordinary deal, and one cannot avoid a certain amount of mild amusement at the idea of this joint consultative committee operating under the chairmanship of the Lord President of the Council.
We heard the right hon. Gentleman this afternoon when he tried to explain how the Labour Party had refurbished all its internal political communication arrangments and how it will consult all the various groups. There will be an immense complex of discussions, and it remains to be seen whether anything at all will happen.
At any rate, the Liberal Party has come away with nothing that it can put in the bank. I agree with my right hon. Friend the Member for Chipping Barnet (Mr. Maudling) that the Liberals have been sold a pup. This new and strange shotgun wedding is their own business, however.
I welcome what the Prime Minister said about Northern Ireland. As he knows very well, we have been pressing for some time that this matter should be looked at under a conference convened under your chairmanship, Mr. Speaker. We have accepted for a long time that the representation of the Northern Ireland constituencies is not fair or reasonable, and so we welcome that aspect.
There always has been respect for a party that has advocated radical change, even among those who disagreed with whatever was proposed. But there is little respect for a party that suddenly finds it convenient to sell its principles to borrow time in order just to survive.
This arrangement will enable the Labour Party to survive in impotence. Whatever else the Liberal Party will do to the Labour Party, it will not bring it potency. Impotence is not government, and today Britain wants government which is inherently strong and responsive to the people's wishes.
The Government are neither of these things, and therefore we have no confidence in them. If the Government expect or want us to have confidence in them, we for our part expect them to be able to count on their own supporters. In recent months they have often not been able to command consent among their own ranks, which is a position of great weakness, particularly for a minority Government.
When the Prime Minister repeats and reasserts, with that bland, disarming smile of his, that, given time, all will be well and that better days are ahead, nobody believes him. There is no evidence to support him. He spoke this afternoon about the "growing prosperity of our people", but for the first time in a long while the standard of living is going down. If it is not, why not have an election? I think that the Prime Minister has altered that comforting phrase that he liked to use in the 1960s and has used once or twice during the last two or three years; he has adjusted his message to "Steady as she is supposed to go".
In proposing this motion we are not just criticising the Government for their failed policies; failed because they have brought us to the bottom of the European tables in economic growth and output and to the top of the tables, unhappily, in
unemployment, inflation, taxation and borrowing. Even if they win tonight, we do not believe that their future policies or future decisions will be any better. Nor are we just criticising the Government for the nature of their legislation, with which we have often disagreed root and branch.
Both of those are good reasons why we think that the Government should go, but there is more to it than that. Our experience of them over three years, but especially during the last nine months, gives us no confidence in the way in which they have handled their decisions or managed their business, particularly in Parliament. To judge from their behaviour in the House, anyone would imagine that they had been elected with an overwhelming majority, that they commanded the support of most of the British people. They have bludgeoned their way, or lime tried to bludgeon their way, through the House with their measures regardless of the arguments and regardless of what other people thought. The evidence of the Scotland and Wales Bill is completely conclusive of the Government's attitude.
If challenged they rely on their little red book. They rely on their manifesto, on which they place such tremendous importance and which has been a menace to this country during the last three years. They wave it in the air self-righteously as though the British people had elected them to carry it out to the letter.
They were not elected on that basis. They were elected on a different basis. It was on a basis that required them to have regard for the fact that less than 40 per cent. of the voters supported them and the other 60 per cent. had the right to be considered, and yet, through by-election after by-election, although they lost their overall majority they continued to act in the same high-handed manner until it was too late.

In view of what the right hon. Gentleman said about the little red book, the manifesto, and the fact that we are fully committed to it, are we to assume that any future Tory Party manifesto should be ignored from the word "go"?

That is a rather facile interpretation of what I said. All I know is that too few of the voters perhaps read
or were able to read all the small print in that manifesto.
Our principal indictment is that the Government have not acted first and foremost in the national interest. They have been motivated primarily and preeminently by their own party interests. Of course they are entitled to work to stay in office and they have come to a new arrangement today to try to achieve that, but to stay in office is not the top priority. It is the national interest that comes first.
I do not believe that there has ever been a Government as brazen as this, and I hope that there will never be another. They have flouted the law. No fewer than three Cabinet Ministers have acted in a way that the courts have declared invalid. They went beyond their powers, challenging the courts in each case, and it was found that they had acted beyond their powers. There was no sign of remorse or apology.
Worse than that, they have bent the law to their own political advantage. Obvious examples of this are Clay Cross, the surcharging of councillors in Scotland and the attempt to repay vast sums of money to trade unions that had refused to register. They tried to bend the law to save Labour Party Members from the consequences of their own actions.
That is utterly wrong and a disastrous example to set. They were not content even with that. The Government have started to abuse both the spirit and the functions of this House. The first example of this was the Aircraft and Shipbuilding Industries Bill. When the Bill was found to be hybrid, the House was asked to set aside the Standing Order so as to set aside the hybridity. What an error of judgment that was on the part of the Leader of the House! We know that it led to the cheated vote and we know that the Prime Minister agreed in the end to re-run it. But he did not hurry to do so. He did not do it at once. He took some time to consider whether he could get away with it in some other way. The Government were wrong-footed on that Bill, and it was ultimately disqualified due to the satisfactory working of our procedures, which are designed to protect the interests of individuals.
Then there was the shabby incident of trying to maintain a majority in Standing
Committees, even though the Government lost their overall majority. I find it difficult to imagine any Leader of the House worthy of that name recommending such a course. Again, in the end, the Prime Minister agreed to do what was right, but why did he ever think what was done right in the first place?
Then there was last Thursday's fiasco, which may yet, although it is unlikely now, turn out to be a boomerang of a lethal kind, because it was a schizophrenic notion, that by not putting the motion to the House in some way the House would not have disagreed. That is an extraordinary proposition.
The right hon. Member for Down, South (Mr. Powell) in a recent article about Parliament and parliamentary responsibility wrote: Our liberties are literally at issue every day on the floor of the House of Commons, assailed, defended, impaired, renewed. That, more than anything else, is what the House of Commons is for. How right that is! The Government's new ploy is not to put their policy to the vote so that the House can assail, reject and criticise without coming to any conclusion and with impunity for the Government. The Government want to continue as though nothing has happened. What a farce, what a travesty of parliamentary democracy!
This time the Prime Minister did not volunteer to do the right thing himself. He did not table a vote of confidence in himself—perhaps he does not have any. Certainly he did not seem to know what advice to give to his hon. Friends the other night about whether to adjourn the House. I do not think that behaviour about that incident was at all right, correct, or proper. At a time when politicians are talking about upholding the rule of law, those are awful examples of what the Government are doing. That is the principal reason for our motion of censure tonight.
We also had the little incident of the Scotland and Wales Bill. The Government say that their purpose was to improve the government of the United Kingdom, particularly that in Scotland and Wales. I am sorry, but I do not believe that. The purpose behind the Bill was to try to appease the nationalists and save Labour seats. When they found before the Second Reading vote that they were not doing the trick, they began amending
it and they continued to amend it to try to placate a rebel here and to save a Labour vote there.
In the end their purpose was so transparent, so unacceptable and so wrong that they achieved the amazing feat of turning a majority in favour of the Bill on Second Reading into a majority against it three months later on a timetable motion. They preferred to try to pass the Bill as a party measure. They lost the argument and lost the Bill.

Will the right hon. Gentleman say why, when the Bill got such a majority on Second Reading, Conservative Members acted so obstructively towards that Bill thereafter? What does the Conservative Party offer as an alternative to devolution?

Nobody in this party—indeed nobody in the House—obstructed the Bill in any way, and the Lord President knows that. The argument on the Bill was won by the House of Commons.
On the second part of the hon. Gentleman's intervention, I wish to tell him that there is no point in going ahead with a measure of this kind unless it would generally benefit the people of Scotland or Wales. The only way to do that is to negotiate across the party lines and try to obtain an agreed solution.
The fact is that all parties for one reason or another are dissatisfied with the Government and their disastrous policies. All parties want to see a change—and that goes for the Liberals as for the nationalists, and the Scottish Labour Party. Certainly the Opposition want to see a change, and many Labour Members too, would like to see a change of policy. Every party and many Labour Members have different reasons and varying objectives, but change is thought by most to be necessary. The Gangway on the Government side of the House is a far deeper chasm in the Labour Party than has ever existed before in the party.
The first change that is needed relates to defence. I agreed with my right hon. Friend the Member for Farnham (Mr. Macmillan) that, although we are faced with increased strength among potential enemies, we are suffering increasing weakness in our defences under the Labour
Government. We recently had the shabby incident involving gratuities. I was grateful that the Government put that right yesterday, but they should not have contemplated changing the situation in the first place.
There is then the important matter of food supplies. Only two years ago the Government published a White Paper entitled "Food from our own resources". That called for increased agricultural production, but the Government have taken no action whatever to implement it. They have taken stop-gap measures. They have no policy, but merely hope for the best.
What is most important in that connection, as in others, is the standing, authority and respect commanded by the British Government in the councils of Europe within the EEC. I regret to say that the Labour Government have brought the reputation of Britain in those councils to a new low level. One of the most powerful reasons for changing the Government is to restore our standing and respect in those councils.
I turn to industrial strategy, pay and price controls and the social contract, described by the right hon. Member for Huyton (Sir H. Wilson) as the boldest experiment of civilised government Britain has ever seen. What has it produced? It has brought about the highest inflation we have ever experienced, bringing unemployment levels to the highest levels in our history. The social contract is coming under more and more criticism and seems to be cracking because one partner is demanding more and more and the other partner is giving less and less.
Industrial strategy is not working, because price controls are too severe and profits too low for business to be able to thrive. If we want expansion and new jobs, as we all do, we must replace that policy and see that there is less interference, less taxation and less public spending, and we must create more profit, more investment and more job creation.
The Government's present economic strategy is not working. It cannot work and it will not work. Last month the Prime Minister said: We need more jobs, but I do not know the answer. That is not very encouraging.
We have heard much about the myth of the so-called economic miracle that is so often mentioned by the Chancellor of the Exchequer. He mentioned that miracle in his Budget last year, and said in April last year: All that is required is a marginal improvement in industrial performance. That will suffice to produce the economic miracle. Then, having said in July that the economic miracle was within our grasp, he said in December: What I have always said is that no Government can produce the economic miracle. The Prime Minister, with his great attention to "The Right Approach" has commented upon the passage that states that the economic miracle is not round the corner. That is correct. That is what we have been saying consistently to the country, not what the Government have been saying.
There are other areas of policy where we want a change and a fresh start. Housing is one such area. There is not time to go into the details, but everyone knows of the disastrous state that our housing has reached under the policies pursued by the Government. Too many houses are empty. Lettings have dried up. Too few new houses are being built, and there are masses of unsatisfied demands from those who want to own their own houses.
We want to replace the prejudices of the Labour Party with better opportunities for people who want to own their own houses. We want to make better use of our housing stock.
We want a big change in taxation. Present taxation is far too high. It is unacceptably high. It has given rise to resentment. That is unhealthy for our society, because it has induced and encouraged people to fiddle. I regret to have to say so, but the Labour Party of all parties has turned this country, and is turning it, into something that might be described as an expense account society. That is a very bad idea.
We think we know that the Chancellor will make a substantial reduction in taxation, but we are certain that the Liberal Party, the Government's newfound partner, will have no influence on the Budget or economic policy. I repeat that taxation is at far too high a level.
I return to the parliamentary situation because it is the Government's behaviour and conduct of parliamentary matters that I find most offensive. The malady from which the Government suffer has not occurred suddenly. The patient has a long list of ailments. His medical history, if I may use that analogy, began with the public expenditure debate a year ago. The stricken patient was revived by a vote of confidence and warned that that dangerous drug was never to be taken again.
The next incident was the procedure motion on hybridity. The patient paid no attention and collapsed again over the Dock Work Regulation Bill. Sirens blew and the ambulance came. The patient was taken to the intensive care unit. He recovered and then recklessly went out on the tiles with the Scotland and Wales Bill.
The patient insisted on pulling one limb here and wrenching another there until something approaching complete dislocation was reached. So much had gone wrong by then that the patient looked round for relief. He saw a bottle labelled "Public Expenditure". He remembered the warning, but felt a sense of compulsion. He thought no one was looking, he took a swig and that was it. Everyone except the patient realised then and realises now that the Government were in their death-throes.
We are asking the House to take the kinder course, although that seems unlikely now because the Government have discovered a new drug called "Liberal". That will not last much longer than the last drug. We are asking that the British people be given the opportunity to put a big notice at the foot of the patient's bed that will state "Not to be resuscitated". The liberties of the British people can be sustained only if the laws of the land and the privileges, rights and duties of this Parliament and the House of Commons, which have been fought for, won and preserved over so many years, are respected, upheld and maintained inviolate.
It is the responsibility of every hon. Member to have full regard to the protection of the House, but it is the prime responsibility of the Government of the day to safeguard and nurture the wellbeing of Parliament. However, it is the Government's arrogance towards the
House and towards the laws of the land that threatens to undermine the very institutions on which the continued freedom and liberties of the British people rest. That is why we condemn them and challenge them tonight.

speech.speakername: The Lord President of the Council and Leader of the House of Commons (Mr. Michael Foot)
speech.p:
Sandwiched between some of his remarks, which I took to be critical of the Government in some senses, the right hon. Member for Cambrideshire (Mr. Pym) welcomed the comments made by my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister about Northern Ireland. I should like to take a few minutes to refer to some of the conversations that we had on that subject and to emphasise some of the points made by my right hon. Friend.
My right hon. Friend and I have on a number of occasions made clear that we accept that Northern Ireland is underrepresented in this House, whether some acceptable devolution settlement for the Province is achieved or not. Having considered that matter further, we are now prepared to propose, as we have indicated, that this should be one of the matters to be considered by a Speaker's Conference as soon as agreement can be reached between the parties that such a conference should be established.
Will my right hon. Friend give way?

I shall give way to my hon. Friend later.
We have also had discussions on the question of local government in Northern Ireland. We are prepared to consider those discussions in association with all concerned. We made it clear to the hon. Member for Antrim, South (Mr. Molyneaux) in the discussions that we had with him. In the course of those discussions, as he will recall, certain matters concerning security were raised. I think that the hon. Gentleman understood and accepted that, while we were eager that he and his colleagues should make representations to us at any time that they wished, as they did to the Prime Minister a week ago, none the less we believed that it would be improper to make the question of security part of any such understanding.

Will the Leader of the House tell us whether in these discussions, in return for the concession of a Speaker's Conference, he received any undertaking from right hon. and hon. Members representing Ulster constituencies that they were prepared to concede the principle of power-sharing at all levels in local government and devolution?

We emphasised our own commitment to those principles. We made it clear to the hon. Member for Antrim, South that we would be prepared to agree to the reference to a Speaker's Conference irrespective of any other consideration. I think that was the right way to proceed and the right way for the whole matter to be clarified in the country. It would have been wrong for us to deal with the matter otherwise. I hope that right hon. and hon. Members on both sides of the House will agree that that was the proper way for us to proceed.
I turn now to some of the other discussions which have been held with and to speeches which have been made by representatives of other parties. I shall come to some of the more controversial questions posed by the right hon. Member for Western Isles (Mr. Stewart) later. No one could say that the Leader of the Scottish National Party was not controversial in his remarks. I should certainly acquit him of being non-controversial. None the less, I hope that he and all those hon. Members who have sought a devolution settlement for Scotland and Wales—and we are committed to a devolution measure for both countries—will understand that we wish to proceed as fast as possible with such a proposal. We know that there are some obstacles but we want to try to get satisfactory legislation on the statute book.
We have had discussions with the Leader of the Liberal Party on this as well as with some of my hon. Friends. As the Prime Minister indicated today, we are of course, quite prepared for further discussion on those matters but we believe that it is fully possible to get a satisfactory measure for devolution on the statute book within this Parliament. That is the determination of the Government and only this Government can carry that into effect.

Is the Leader of the House not deluding
himself about the Government being able to deliver a devolution Bill? The Government introduced a Bill into the House, as I recollect, and it was put to a timetable motion, but the Government's own supporters stabbed it in the back. Does the right hon. Gentleman not realise that we in Scotland can no longer trust the English Labour Party and that we want an election in Scotland now?

The hon. Gentleman speaks for some people in Scotland, but many of my hon. Friends speak for more people there. The great majority for whom they speak wish to see a proper devolution settlement coupled with the maintenance of the unity of the United Kingdom. This party represents that policy and we seek to carry it into full effect.
I now turn to some of the other discussions that have given rise to interest in the debate, particularly the discussions that we have had with the leaders of the Liberal Party. [HON. MEMBERS: "Where are they?"] It is a little hard for the Liberal Party to be criticised in that way because it appears that some of the great Conservative defenders of the House of Commons now sitting on the Liberal Bench want to turn the House into the fifth form at St. Dominic. Nothing that they have done tonight is likely to contribute to the dignity of the House. The Leader of the Liberal Party is now sitting on the Opposition Front Bench. It is agreeable to be able to deal with him at close quarters. If the fifth form at St. Dominic would keep quiet we should like to get on with the debate.
I wish to make clear to the House—and I am sure that the Leader of the Liberal Party will confirm this—that right at the beginning of our discussions it was clearly agreed that whatever conclusion was reached would be made public in every particular, and that is what we have done. In order to remove any misapprehensions that any of my hon. Friends may have, let me make it clear—although it is clear from the text that has been published—that there is no question of any coalition. Nothing of the sort was ever suggested by the right hon. Gentleman or by my right hon. and hon. Friends on that subject. Nor is there any question of any Lib-Lab pact as has been discussed in previous years. It is
an agreement between us, made in good faith on both sides, to try to make this Session of Parliament workable in the interests of the nation and the people.
rose—

Order. We can have only one hon. Member on his feet at any one time and I cannot resist reminding the House that there was reasonable quiet for the right hon. Member for Cambridgeshire (Mr. Pym), who wound up for the Opposition.

We are seeking by this agreement to make this Session workable in the interests of Parliament and of the two parties concerned with us. If, at the end of the Session, we discover that it has been a successful experiment, we can have discussions on whether it should be continued.
I know that there are some who would prefer to make Parliament unworkable. The Leader of the Opposition and her Friends are among them, and it appears from the statements of the leaders of the nationalist parties that they would like to make Parliament unworkable. One thing that will be made perfectly clear by tonight's vote is that the majority of hon. Members want to make Parliament workable and that we are not prepared to have it sabotaged by those who talk of their allegiance to parliamentary government but who seek to sabotage it.

I am grateful to the right hon. Gentleman for giving way and I shall wait a while until hon. Members opposite have shut up. The right hon. Gentleman referred to "the nation". The whole point about his Front Bench's programme is that it is pledged to talk about the "nations" of the British Isles and not the "nation". The right hon. Gentleman's tongue slipped in the usual old arch-imperialist way. Would he care to reflect on what the people of Scotland will think about that?

I shall think about it. I do not know whether it deserves much more than that at the moment.
I listened with care as, I am sure, did the whole House when it was allowed to, while my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister was speaking earlier. It was a
very good speech, but in one sentence he was a little unfair to the Conservatives. He said that the country had no idea what the Opposition's policy was on a large number of subjects. I think that there are some subjects on which their policy is perfectly clear.—[HON. MEMBERS: "Get on with it."] I am filling in the gaps.
The Leader of the Opposition and the right hon. Member for Cambridgeshire did not tell us what their policies were. It is clear that the Leader of the Opposition and her Front Bench repudiate any kind of incomes policy such as was operated by the right hon. Member for Sidcup (Mr. Heath). There is no doubt about that. It is also true that the right hon. Lady, her hon. Friends and the right hon. Member for Cambridgeshire repudiate any policy on devolution such as was advocated by the right hon. Member for Sidcup. It is true that they have repudiated any return to the kind of industrial legislation put through by the right hon. Member for Sidcup.
There is therefore a large range of matters on which their policy is absolutely clear. Indeed, it seems to me that sometimes the right hon. Lady has worked on the principle of people approaching her and saying "See what Ted did and do thou otherwise." I thought that that was not a bad prescription with which to start off.
Opposition hon. Members cannot say that they come to the House and the country as a united party. There has been some talk of an election, but when I look at the right hon. Member for Sidcup I see that there is not much of an election fever there. The right hon. Gentleman has been keeping himself well under control.
The right hon. Member for Leeds, North-East (Sir K. Joseph) is not in the same position—and here I approach the essential matter. There is a gulf of difference between them, even if I have not got the actual area right. The right hon. Member for Leeds, North-East will not contest anything that I have said about the sharp distinction between his policies and those of his right hon. Friend the Member for Sidcup because, when he addressed the Young Conservatives the other day and referred to the Leader of
the Opposition's policy to fight inflation, he said: I was one of the villains as Social Services Secretary because I spent your money. But I am a reformed character now. Here, before me, are the reformed characters and over there are the old lags.
It is not only that. The right hon. Member for Leeds, North-East said "I was an inflationeer". He need not tell us that. We had to come in and take it over when we got into power in February and March 1974. At that time there was already over 20 per cent. inflation in the pipeline, as the right hon. Gentleman knows.
The right hon. Member for Leeds, North-East says that he is reformed character. Presumably all his right hon. and hon. Friends are reformed characters—except the hon. Member for Oswestry (Mr. Biffen), who went into the reformatory camp but could not stand it any more. He returned to the fresh breezes of the Tory Back Benches where they did not have reform at all. We have now got the matter clearly sorted out.
There is another matter upon which the Conservative Party has declared its policy. I am gratified that it has been made clear to us all. I would have thought that instead of criticising me they would have been most grateful, because I am the first person in the debate who has tried to indicate the meaning of their policy. I always try to assist the right hon. Lady the Leader of the Opposition. Her recent performances have not interfered with my fondness for her in any way. I have often told her—and I tell her now—that if I had had a vote in her leadership contest I would have voted for her. That is more than I can say about my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister. Ah, well—both parties got what they deserved.
The right hon. Lady fully lived up to my expectations today. She is performing very satisfactorily from the point of view of all of us. Her only mistake was when she over-reached herself slightly last Thursday, when I thought that she hoped that she would be able to entice into the Division Lobby—[HON. MEMBERS: "Enticed?"] I know that some hon. Members do not like this very much,
but this was the origin of this supposed motion of censure, which has not yet been resolved. The origin of it was that the right hon. Lady thought that she would be able to entice into the Lobby to defeat us last Thursday all the waifs and strays, if I may describe them in that way. [HON. MEMBERS: "Oh"] If hon. Members do not like associating with them, they need not follow them into the Lobby. There is no compulsion on them. I am sure that some hon. Members who have been thinking out these matters will be thinking them out afresh before they go into the Lobby with the right hon. Lady.

The right hon. Gentleman will be as well aware as are we on the SNP Bench that the Conservatives did not put in Tellers on that occasion. They relied upon us to do so. I think that he would agree that by doing so we not only embarrassed his Government but the Conservatives also.

I hope that the hon. Gentleman will work out carefully what he has said. He admits to the House that the Conservative Front Bench relied upon him to assist the Conservatives on that occasion. I hope that they will be very careful before they do that again. In fact, they must watch these matters very carefully.
There has been some talk of arrangements and opportunist positions. The most opportunist thing that will happen tonight—if it happens—is that Conservative Members will go into the Aye Lobby in their party interests and SNP Members, according to their present indications, will troop into the same Lobby in pursuit of their interests. Neither group has the same interests—unless there has been a remarkable conversion on one side or another—and all that will happen if hon. Members of the SNP on the Opposition side of the House decide to do it, is that they will cast aspersions even on their own dedication to the programe of devolution. They should be fully capable of working out, just as everyone else in the country will be able to work it out, that it is only a Labour Government who can carry into legislation the programe for providing the Scottish Assembly and the Welsh Assembly and meeting all the other
promises of that kind that have been made.

In that case, will the right hon. Gentleman answer the question put by the hon. Member for South Ayrshire (Mr. Sillars) and by myself? Why did the Government not make this issue an issue of confidence, if they so believe in devolution?

I know what the hon. Gentleman wanted and what some other hon. Members wanted, and what some others want for their own interest. The hon. Member for Moray and Nairn (Mrs. Ewing) wants devolution. We understand her reasons. What other hon. Members wanted was to secure the defeat of the present Government. Of course they are angry, because it will not happen. That is the reason for the exhibition that we have had from the Opposition Benches.
There is a story in the Arabian Nights of a Barmecide feast, when wonderful dishes were spread out in front of the diners and snatched away at the last moment. The feast vanished. That is the reason for the expression on the faces of the Leader of the Opposition and her colleagues. They had hoped to come here tonight and inflict a serious defeat on the Labour Government. They hoped they would interrupt the whole programme that this Labour Government have carried into effect. They hoped that they would be able to seize all the advantages and pretend that they arose from their own actions and deeds. But they have been thwarted and the dish has been snatched away from them.
My hon. Friends in the Tribune Group will be especially interested in the fact that the person who was gesturing at them is the Tory Chief Whip. I am sure that my hon. Friends, and even my hon. Friend the Member for South Ayrshire (Mr. Sillars), will never fall for a trick perpetrated by the hon. Gentleman and his hon. Friends.
Is my right hon. Friend aware that his analogy with the Arabian Nights is an apt one because in October 1974 the Labour Government laid before
the Scottish working people a pledge of a Scottish Assembly and 44 Labour Members of Parliament have snatched that away? The only way that will be restored is by a vote of confidence.

My hon. Friend is mistaken. The only way in which that part of our manifesto will be carried into effect is if the Labour Government stays in office and if we secure the votes of sufficient people to carry it through. That is the way in which it will be done. If my hon. Friend effectively votes against us tonight, he will be destroying that possibility and he will help to destroy all the things that he and I, and other hon. Members, have fought for many years to sustain.
We therefore do not propose to be enticed by any of the right hon. Lady's stratagems. We do not propose to allow the Conservative Opposition to dictate what is to be the political scene in the coming months and years. We shall faithfully carry through the agreement that we have made both with the Liberals and with our own party. We shall carry it through openly. The whole country will be able to see what we in this Parliament are doing. And as we make it work and succeed we shall sustain Parliament and we shall show that Parliament, even in the difficult circumstances of a narrow majority, can effectively carry great measures into operation.
We can carry many other great measures, measures which for years to come provide a great constitutional settlement for the whole of the United Kingdom. That is one of the prizes that we have before us in this Parliament. I invite the whole House to throw out with contempt this vote of no confidence tonight and say that this Government shall carry on until the time when a Labour Prime Minister chooses the date for the next election.

speech.p: The House divided: Ayes 298; Noes 322.
